titleInfo.title: Covid-19 and Elections as Triggers of Racially Motivated and Extremist Crime
titleInfo.subTitle: Temporal Analyses of Hate Crime in Slovakia

name.namePart: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
College of Criminology and Criminal Justice

mods:mods.abstract: Historically, hate crime research has been relatively nonexistent in Central and Eastern Europe. Yet, this region and others in the West, increasingly witness violent incitements and targeted attacks against minority communities, largely owing to significant democratic backsliding and rising immigration levels. The Slovak Republic, therefore, provides an interesting setting for bias crime evaluation. This thesis evaluates the impacts of two important events – pandemics and elections – in generating racially motivated and extremist crimes in Slovakia. The nation's interrelation between migration, race, socioeconomic status, and social identity offers several important and potential drivers of bias-motivated violence. Applying data from the Ministry of Interior of the Slovak Republic and the Statistical Office of the Slovak Republic, the present research suggests four main outcomes related to hate crimes across Slovak regions. First, the COVID-19 pandemic did not show any hate crime effects unless conditioned by employment and immigration status. This signifies that the pandemic, once conditioned, did influence hate crime rates in Slovak regions with high levels of immigration and low male employment rates. Second, the interactive effects of the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and immigration and employment rates were delayed. Third, data indicates that extreme right parties matter, wherein the more they are perceived as legitimate, such as receiving higher electoral vote-shares, the higher the bias crime rate. Hence, there is a vital emphasis on extreme right support, legitimization, and mobilization in effecting Slovak political outcomes and hate crime incidence. Lastly, high immigration rates strengthen the effect of vote-shares on bias crime. While this thesis was unable to definitively provide causalities of COVID-19 and extreme right electoral support on hate crime in Slovakia, the analyses indicate several important markers of a potentially hostile social environment that is conducive to hate crime occurrence.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the College of Criminology and Criminal Justice in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Criminal Justice Studies.
COVID-19, Elections, Hate Crime, Pandemics, Right-wing, Slovakia
Sylwia J. Piatkowska, Professor Directing Thesis; Marin R. Wenger, Committee Member; Brendan Lantz, Committee Member.

etd:degree.etd:name: Master of Arts
etd:degree.etd:discipline: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
